<div class="inlineModule byline">

4:54 <span class="seg">pm ET</span>
<span class="visually-hidden updated">4:54 <span class="seg">pm
ET</span></span>

<div class="name name-with-headshot" data-author="By Alan Rappeport" style="background-image: url(&#39;https://static01.graylady3jvrrxbe.onion/images/2014/09/22/us/politics/Alan-Rappeport/First-Draft-avatars-slide-UQ7D-thumbLarge.png&#39;);">

<span class="fn">By Alan
Rappeport</span>

</div>

<div class="shareTools sharetools theme-classic sharetools-story" data-shares="facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet" data-url="//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/28/on-this-day-there-you-go-again/" data-title="On This Day: ‘There You Go Again’" data-description="On this day in 1980, Ronald Reagan, the former governor of California, showed how congeniality could be a winning strategy. ">

</div>

</div>

# [On This Day: ‘There You Go Again’](//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/28/on-this-day-there-you-go-again/ "Permanent link to On This Day: ‘There You Go Again’")

<div class="hide-on-viewport-medium byline">

4:54 <span class="seg">pm ET</span>
<span class="visually-hidden updated">4:54 <span class="seg">pm
ET</span></span>

<div class="name name-with-headshot" data-author="By Alan Rappeport" style="background-image: url(&#39;https://static01.graylady3jvrrxbe.onion/images/2014/09/22/us/politics/Alan-Rappeport/First-Draft-avatars-slide-UQ7D-thumbLarge.png&#39;);">

<span class="author vcard" itemprop="author creator" itemtype="//schema.org/Person">
By </span>

<span class="fn" itemprop="name">Alan
Rappeport</span>

</div>

<div class="shareTools sharetools theme-classic sharetools-story" data-shares="facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet" data-url="//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/28/on-this-day-there-you-go-again/" data-title="On This Day: ‘There You Go Again’" data-description="On this day in 1980, Ronald Reagan, the former governor of California, showed how congeniality could be a winning strategy. ">

</div>

</div>

<div class="w480">

![<span class="caption-text"></span><span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder"><span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
</span>](https://static01.graylady3jvrrxbe.onion/packages/images/reagancarter.png)

</div>

Debates during this midterm election cycle have been notable largely for
their
[saltiness](//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/16/?entry=mb-3)
and the [occasional backhanded
compliment](//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/23/?entry=3311&_php=true&_type=blogs&ref=politics).

But on this day in 1980, Ronald Reagan, the former governor of
California and the Republican presidential nominee, showed how
congeniality could be a winning strategy.

In the only debate of the campaign, Mr. Reagan sought to be calm and
reassuring in contrast to President Jimmy Carter’s focus on scoring
points with sharp retorts, The New York Times reported at the time.

While the candidates differed over economic strategy and taxes, the
debate was made memorable by Mr. Reagan’s “there you go again” remark
(insisting that Mr. Carter was misrepresenting his positions) and when
Mr. Reagan asked viewers: “Are you better off than you were four years
ago?”

The Times reported that there was “no clear winner” in the debate. A
week later, there was, as Mr. Reagan won the election
handily.

<div class="hide-on-viewport-medium sharetools-footer">

<div class="shareTools sharetools theme-classic sharetools-story" data-shares="facebook|Share,twitter|Tweet" data-url="//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/politics/first-draft/2014/10/28/on-this-day-there-you-go-again/" data-title="On This Day: ‘There You Go Again’" data-description="On this day in 1980, Ronald Reagan, the former governor of California, showed how congeniality could be a winning strategy. ">

</div>

</div>

</div>

<div class="module nocontent">

#### About First Draft

First Draft provides fast-paced and comprehensive coverage of politics
and elections by The New York Times. Come back throughout the day for
the latest news and analysis, and be part of the political conversation.

  
Like it? Hate it? Have a tip for us? Send any and all feedback to
<firstdraft@NYTimes.com>.

</div>

<div class="module nocontent follow-module">

#### Politics Newsletter

<div class="brief-container">

We send out a newsletter around 7 a.m. eastern time each weekday that
serves as a look-ahead to the day's political events and expected
stories.

[Sign
    Up](//www.nytimes3xbfgragh.onion/newsletters/politics/)

</div>
